K\bar{K}K
L\bar{L}L
>\alpha > \beta>

children.value: Consider a small-open economy with two production sectors -- agriculture and manufacturing -- with production in each sector taking place with constant returns to scale production functions.  Producers in the agricultural sector maximize profits
\max_{K_A,L_A} p_A F(K_A,L_A) - w L_A - r K_A
children.html: maxKA,LApAF(KA,LA)wLArKA\max_{K_A,L_A} p_A F(K_A,L_A) - w L_A - r K_AKA,LAmaxpAF(KA,LA)wLArKA

children.value: \max_{K_M,L_M} p_M G(K_M,L_M) - w L_M - r K_M
children.html: maxKM,LMpMG(KM,LM)wLMrKM\max_{K_M,L_M} p_M G(K_M,L_M) - w L_M - r K_MKM,LMmaxpMG(KM,LM)wLMrKM

children.value: In equilibrium total factor demands must equal total supplies:

children.html: KA+KM=KK_A + K_M = \bar KKA+KM=K
LA+LM=LL_A + L_M = \bar LLA+LM=L

children.value: The first order necessary conditions for an interior optimum in each sector lead to an equilibrium where the following condition must hold:

\frac{F_L(K_A,L_A)}{F_K(K_A,L_A)} = \frac{w}{r} 
       =\frac{G_L(\bar K-K_A,\bar L- L_A)}{G_K(\bar K-K_A,\bar L- L_A)}
children.html: FL(KA,LA)FK(KA,LA)=wr=GL(KKA,LLA)GK(KKA,LLA)\frac{F_L(K_A,L_A)}{F_K(K_A,L_A)} = \frac{w}{r} =\frac{G_L(\bar K-K_A,\bar L- L_A)}{G_K(\bar K-K_A,\bar L- L_A)}FK(KA,LA)FL(KA,LA)=rw=GK(KKA,LLA)GL(KKA,LLA)

children.value: Efficiency requires that the marginal rates of technical substitution (MRTS) be equalized across sectors (and across firms within a sector which is being assumed here). In an Edgeworth box, isoquants from each sector will be tangent to a common wage-rental ratio line.

children.html: F(K,L)=KL1F(K,L) = K^\alpha L^{1-\alpha}F(K,L)=KL1
G(K,L)=KL1G(K,L) = K^\beta L^{1-\beta}G(K,L)=KL1

children.value: the efficiency condition can be used to find a closed form solution for

children.html: KAK_AKA
LAL_ALA
(1)KALA=wr=(1)KKALLA\frac{(1-\alpha)}{\alpha}\frac{K_A}{L_A} =\frac{w}{r} =\frac{(1-\beta)}{\beta}\frac{\bar K-K_A}{\bar L-L_A}(1)LAKA=rw=(1)LLAKKA

children.html: LA=50L_A = 50LA=50

children.value: units of labor are allocated to the agricultural sector and all other allocations are efficient (along the efficiency locus).
also allows us to trace out the production possibility frontier: by varying

KA(LA)K_A(L_A)KA(LA)
(QA,QM)(Q_A,Q_M)(QA,QM)
QA=F(KA(LA),LA)Q_A=F(K_A(L_A), L_A)QA=F(KA(LA),LA)
QM=G(KKA(LA),LLA)Q_M=G(\bar K - K_A(L_A), \bar L - L_A)QM=G(KKA(LA),LLA)

children.value: The curvature of the PPF depends on how different the factor intensities are:

children.html: \alpha \approx \beta

children.value: (similar factor intensities): PPF is nearly straight

children.html: \alpha \gg \beta
\alpha \ll \beta

children.value: (very different intensities): PPF is more curved
For Cobb-Douglas technologies the PPF will be quite straight unless

children.html: \beta
\alpha

children.value: are very different from each other. In practical terms, this means that quite small changes to product prices will move production around quite a bit when factor intensities are similar.
Jump to the notebook on the

to see a very practical application of the Edgeworth Box and this basic model framework and derive a number of theorems regarding how a small open economy will respond to a change in world relative prices or factor endowments.
If youre reading this using a jupyter server you can interact with the following plot, changing the technology parameters and position of the isoquant. If you are not this may appear blank or static.

LA = 50
interact(edgeplot, LA=(10, Lbar-10,1), 
         Kbar=fixed(Kbar), Lbar=fixed(Lbar),
         alpha=(0.1,0.9,0.1),beta=(0.1,0.9,0.1));
